title: Before 1 October 2021, will Jair Bolsonaro cease to be the president of Brazil?
preds: President Bolsonaro is playing by the U.S. previous President's playbook. Stay in power for as long as possible and squash any opposition that stands in his way. If feel threatened by the election, publicly question the validity of the election. I am not judging Brazilians or the system but the individual solely.
The deadline is to short. It's  almost impossible.

Brazil Politics: Bolsonaro Says He Won't Doubt Voting System - Bloomberg
https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2021-09-24/brazil-politics-bolsonaro-says-he-won-t-doubt-voting-system
Fri, 24 Sep 2021 15:59:06 GMT
bf0307d8d6d7807028b86c0a178b6b39 > There’s no more reason to doubt the country’s electronic ballot system now that the military will be involved in the process, the president told Veja magazine, adding that there’s “zero chance” he would seek a coup to remain in power.  Ominous.
Still the president with less than 10 days to go
Late to this table but anywho. With so little time to go, I'm going all in on zero.

While his popularity and disapproval rating have reached record high recently (https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/brazils-bolsonaro-disapproval-rating-rises-all-time-high-poll-2021-07-08/) , ceasing to be the president can only happen if he was toppled, or if he dies. I do not see that happening in the next 10 days.
Maybe he'll be voted out next year, though.

There does not appear to be any mechanisms by which opponents of Bolsonaro could remove him from power in the next two weeks. To some extent, it seems like the most likely way for Bolsonaro to cease to be president in the short term would be for him to stage a coup and fail.

It is known that Jair Bolsonaro, the current president of Brazil, has been questioned for his mishandling of the COVID-19 crisis in his country. In fact, during the month of August there were more than 30,000 daily infections throughout the month and today (September 7) 9,154 new cases were reported. On the other hand, his popularity fell to 24%, the lowest in his term, in addition to the fact that he is being investigated for spreading false information about the elections. However, despite all the controversy in his person, there are a large number of people who support Bolsonaro, showing his favoritism in protest marchs against the judiciary that is investigating him. Some are even calling for a military intervention against the country's Supreme Court. Therefore, I estimate with a probability of 2% that Bolsonaro will cease to be president. I believe that it is more likely that there is a kind of polarization in the population between two sides, for and against the president, which will manifest across the country in the coming months.
Down from 1% due to passage of time (about a month since last forecast).

He continues to live and has no new health issues, which means one potential avenue for his removal is narrowing

His support in the Congress houses and popular opinion is fragile but there is strong resistance to removing him from office. He has sufficient clout over the Lower House's most central block as the basis for their sustain is sufficient for them to not consider impeachment as a possibility. He is being investigated in multiple fronts but the processes are slow and the one with most potential for impeachment is the CPI (Inquiry Parliament Committee) which won't end soon. Besides, Impeachment is the main way that he can be removed, while it also took over two months to succeed under Rousseff's presidency. The last impeachment being not long ago also creates resistance, as the repercussions of Bolsonaro's impeachment would undermine the image of democracy, the people's trust in their chosen candidates, and other factors.
President Bolsonaro still having support among 25/30% of the voters. There is no room to be ceased.
It is snowing in the jungle down there - anything could happen.

He could still die or be impeached, but I think it's looking less likely that he will have to relinquish office that soon.

A pesar de que las próximas elecciones de Brasil son en 2022, creo que de igual forma existe una probabilidad de que  Jair Bolsonaro deje de ser presidente de Brasil antes del 1 de octubre. Una de las principales causas de esto, podría ser la terrible gestión con que ha manejado la pandemia, registrando hasta la fecha más de 360.000 fallecidos y más de 3.600 en la última jornada, eso sumado al bajo porcentaje de vacunación de la población. Otro de lo motivos se podría atribuir a la mala situación económica que el país esta enfrentando ya que en 2020 el PIB brasileño se redujo un 4,1% con relación al año anterior, además el desempleo ha llegado al 15%, su nivel más alto desde 2012, y el coste de la vida se eleva por la alta inflación. Todo lo anterior ha hecho que la aprobación de presidente caiga drásticamente, teniendo un 44% de desaprobación general y un 54% de desaprobación a su gestión de la pandemia. Fri, 12 Mar 2021 17:01:00 GMT But analysts say it is politics, not the growing death toll, that is driving Bolsonaro’s attempt to rebrand his pandemic leadership. Growing pressure from Brazil’s business community to act over the last few months was bolstered this week by the return of a major political rival to the national stage. On Monday, former president Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva – the popular leftist who was excluded from the 2018 election because of corruption charges – had his name cleared by Brazil’s supreme court, freeing him to run against Bolsonaro in 2022. He used his first speech after the verdict to condemn Bolsonaro’s handling of the pandemic. “Do not follow a single one of the president or health minister’s moronic decisions. Get vaccinated,” he told Brazilians on Wednesday

Updating as the timeframe has gotten closer and the probability of outside factors decreases.
Impeachment unlikely given election of allies to speakerships in congress

Allies of President Bolsonaro now control both chambers of Brazil's legislature. (https://www.reuters.com/article/us-brazil-politics/bolsonaro-allies-win-control-of-brazilian-congress-idUSKBN2A12WY?il=0) This development practically ensures that there will not be an impeachment since Bolsonaro's party has successfully received the support of more moderate lawmakers.

There is always a big movement of people wanting and several impeachment requests filed, but he has created an illegal network of supporters in high places of the government, judiciary and legislative that protect him, but recently, even right wing supporters have started requesting for his removal from power.
It is very unlikely that he does get removed (unfortunately) but there is at least a considerable chance that he does, though if that happens, the one to assume power will most likely be Hamilton Mourão, his vice president, which is military and will probably immediately descend this country in a very rigorous military dictatorship.

The elections will be in 2022. Despite all the troubles Bolsonaro is and may be going through in the next months, there's no valid reason for him to step aside or be overthrown by Ocotber 2021 or before the next elections.
I think he's got the military behind him, so October is unlikely.

It seems unlikely that President Bolsonaro will be removed from office before 1 October 2021 due to a number of reasons. First, with Trump's loss in the United States, and a more moderate Biden administration in place, Bolsonaro can reach out to the United States to improve trade relations between the two countries, which will benefit Brazil and bring money and cheaper goods to the country [1]. His approval rating is also at the highest as it has been at anytime in his tenure in office, due to economic measures he has undertaken while in office and it has grown amongst the poorest members of the country [2]. Bolsonaro's party did lose seats in the 2020 elections, but he has the support of a moderate block in Brazil's congress, which makes it seem unlikely that he will be removed from office before the 2022 elections [3]. Thus, I assess there is a 0% probability that President Bolsonaro will case to be President of Brazil before 1 October 2021 [1] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-biden-brazil/brazils-bolsonaro-says-he-wants-free-trade-agreement-with-u-s-in-letter-to-biden-idUSKBN29P2RM

I estimate that there's around a %2.5 chance that Bolsonaro dies before 1st October 2021, based on the actuarial estimate of the chance of death for a 75 year old (about %3.56 per year) multiplied by 5/6 to adjust for the 10 months remaining and further adjusted downwards to account for Bolsonaro not being representative. Out of 8 presidents in the "New Republic" period of Brazil (since 1985), two (Fernando Collor de Mello, Dilma Rousseff) have been forced from office before the end of their term. We may naively estimate that being forced from office is a kind of Poisson process with an arrival rate of once per 17.5 years, in which case the probability that there will be no instance of it occuring in the next 10 months is exp(-lambda) = exp(-(10 months)/(17.5 years)) = %95.3. This gives a %4.7 probability that Bolsonaro will be forced from office before 1st October 2021. Adding these gives a base rate of %7.2 to Bolsonaro's presidency ending before 1st October 2021. I don't know enough about the situation in Brazil to make any kind of adjustment to this base rate, so I'll just round it down to %7.

Where once impeachment talks were gaining traction, Bolsanaro is now enjoying a level of popularity not seen since the beginning of his term in office. The COVID-19 emergency relief payments (i.e. unconditional cash transfers), which significantly improved living conditions in the most economically underprivileged areas of Brazil, have proved particularly helpful.

In Brazil impeachment needs 2/3 majority in Congress and then 2/3 majority in the Senate. The govt coalition has 47% of the seats in Congress. The Senate is 1/3 govt, 4/9 "independents", and 2/9 opposition. However the 4/9 "independents" are all of parties that impeached the previous president, and the current president defines himself most of all in opposition to the previous one. Add to this the ~10 months we have to go, and the fact that impeachment timelines are roughly this long (Rousseff took ~9 months), and widespread calls for impeachment ought already to have started if this was going to resolve positively. So I call the chance of impeachment 0%. This leaves the chance that Bolsonaro dies, which actuarial life tables put at ~1.6% for age 65 over one year. This makes 1.3% for 10 months, but I judge Bolsonaro to be slightly healthier than the average 65yo so I round it down to 1%.
